Description: Bronze key with ring; flat shaft, wards at right angles with three square teeth. L-shaped lift-key, or slide key attached to a ring.
Curator's comments: A number of similar keys were found at Naukratis (Ashmolean Museum AN1888.189; Boston 86.355, 86.354, 86.353; British Museum EA 1885, 1101.82; Fitzwilliam Museum GR.72.1887; Montreal 2522a-c; Petrie Museum UC59869d). Roman parallels from the Fayum and Egypt in the Petrie Museum (UC71705, UC63742, UC63769-77, 83-5, 90; Petrie 1917, 60, pl.76, W. 193 - 200). An L-shaped lift or slide key, used to open a simple tumbler lock, used in the Roman period and found across the Roman Empire, including Britain (where they were used since the late Iron age and throught the Romano-British Period, Manning 1985, 89-93, see type O55). Manning, W. H. 1985. Catalogue of the Romano-British iron tools, fittings and weapons in the British Museum. London : BMP. Petrie, W.M.F. 1917, Tools and Weapons. London. University college, London, and 2,000 outlines from other sources. London.
Bibliographic references: Bronze / Catalogue of the Bronzes in the British Museum. Greek, Roman & Etruscan. (2641)
